keyword: Operating Systems: Computer Science-Based Breakdown
1. Operating System Structure
Monolithic Kernels: Kernels that run all operating system services in kernel space.
Microkernels: Kernels that run minimal services in kernel space and others in user space.
Hybrid Kernels: Combines aspects of monolithic and microkernels.
Exokernels: Minimalistic kernels that give applications more control over hardware.
2. Process Management
Processes: Instances of executing programs.
Process States: Different states of a process (e.g., running, waiting).
Process Control Block (PCB): Data structure containing process information.
Threads: The smallest unit of execution within a process.
User-Level Threads: Managed by a user-level library.
Kernel-Level Threads: Managed by the operating system kernel.
Multithreading Models: Approaches to threading, such as many-to-one, one-to-one, and many-to-many.
3. Scheduling
CPU Scheduling: Determining which processes run at any given time.
Preemptive Scheduling: Allows interruption of a process.
Non-preemptive Scheduling: Runs a process to completion once started.
Scheduling Algorithms: Algorithms for process scheduling.
First-Come, First-Served (FCFS): Processes are scheduled in the order they arrive.
Shortest Job Next (SJN): Selects the process with the smallest execution time.
Round Robin (RR): Each process gets a small unit of CPU time in turn.
Priority Scheduling: Processes are assigned priorities and scheduled accordingly.
Multilevel Queue Scheduling: Multiple queues for different priority levels.
4. Memory Management
Memory Allocation: Techniques for managing system memory.
Fixed Partitioning: Divides memory into fixed-size partitions.
Dynamic Partitioning: Allocates memory dynamically based on process size.
Paging: Divides memory into fixed-size pages.
Segmentation: Divides memory into segments based on logical divisions.
Virtual Memory: Allows execution of processes that may not be completely in memory.
Paging: Uses page tables to map virtual addresses to physical addresses.
Segmentation: Uses segment tables for address mapping.
Page Replacement Algorithms: Determines which pages to swap out.
Least Recently Used (LRU): Replaces the least recently used pages.
First-In-First-Out (FIFO): Replaces the oldest pages in memory.
Optimal Page Replacement: Replaces pages that will not be used for the longest time.
5. Storage Management
File Systems: Methods for storing and organizing files.
File Allocation Table (FAT): A table that maps file blocks on disk.
New Technology File System (NTFS): A file system with advanced features like encryption.
Extended File System (ext3/ext4): Commonly used in Linux.
Disk Scheduling Algorithms: Determines the order in which disk I/O requests are serviced.
FCFS (First-Come, First-Served): Services requests in the order they arrive.
SSTF (Shortest Seek Time First): Selects the request closest to the current head position.
SCAN (Elevator Algorithm): Moves the disk arm across the disk to service requests.
C-SCAN (Circular SCAN): Similar to SCAN but starts again from the beginning.
6. I/O Systems
I/O Hardware: Physical components that perform input and output operations.
I/O Control Methods: Methods to control I/O operations.
Polling: The CPU repeatedly checks the status of an I/O device.
Interrupts: Devices signal the CPU when they need attention.
Direct Memory Access (DMA): Allows devices to transfer data to/from memory without CPU intervention.
7. Security and Protection
Access Control: Mechanisms to regulate access to resources.
Access Control Lists (ACLs): Specifies access rights for each user.
Role-Based Access Control (RBAC): Assigns permissions based on roles.
Authentication: Verifying the identity of users.
Passwords: Secret codes used for authentication.
Biometrics: Uses physical characteristics for identification.
Encryption: Protecting data by converting it into an unreadable format.
Symmetric Encryption: Uses the same key for encryption and decryption.
Asymmetric Encryption: Uses a pair of keys, one for encryption and one for decryption.
8. Networking and Communication
Network Protocols: Rules governing data communication.
TCP/IP: The foundational protocol suite for the internet.
UDP: A connectionless protocol for low-latency communication.
Interprocess Communication (IPC): Mechanisms for processes to communicate.
Pipes: A conduit for data between processes.
Message Queues: Allows messages to be exchanged between processes.
Shared Memory: Multiple processes can access the same memory space.
9. Distributed Systems
Distributed File Systems: File systems that allow access to files across a network.
Network File System (NFS): A protocol for file sharing over a network.
Distributed File System (DFS): Manages files across multiple machines.
Distributed Computing: Processes run on multiple machines to achieve a common goal.
Clusters: Group of linked computers working together as a single system.
Grids: Distributed systems with large-scale resource sharing.
10. Real-Time Systems
Hard Real-Time Systems: Systems with strict timing constraints.
Soft Real-Time Systems: Systems with more lenient timing constraints.
Real-Time Scheduling: Scheduling tasks to meet time constraints.
Rate-Monotonic Scheduling (RMS): Assigns static priorities based on task frequency.
Earliest Deadline First (EDF): Dynamically assigns priorities based on deadlines.
